body.p: First governor of the provisional Confederate government of the state of Kentucky. Member of the Democratic and Southern Rights Parties. Educated at Transylvania University in Lexington, Kentucky. Married Ann Viley. Father of Eliza Woolfolk Johnson, Willa Viley Johnson, Madison Conyers Johnson, Martha Lydia Johnson, Junius Ward Johnson, Warren Viley Johnson, Henry Viley Johnson, and Euclid Lane Johnson. Owned twenty-six enslaved persons in 1860. Practiced law in Georgetown, Kentucky. Farmed in Scott County, Kentucky and Helena, Arkansas. Represented Scott County in the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from 1838 to 1840. Elected first provisional Confederate governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky on November 20, 1861.

bibl.p: Lowell H. Harrison, “George W. Johnson (1861-1862)” in Lowell H. Harrison, Ed., Kentucky’s Governors (Lexington: University Press of Kentucky, 2004), 82-84; Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Scott County, District No 1, p. 31-32.
